questions: A 46-year-old woman presents to surgery complaining of a dry mouth and dry eyes for the past 6 months. She has also generalised arthralgia and is more tired than normal. Which one of the following autoantibodies is most associated with primary Sjogren's syndrome?
notes:
The correct answer is Anti-Ro. Primary Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterised by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands, particularly the salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to symptoms such as dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca). Anti-Ro (also known as SS-A) autoantibodies are found in approximately 60-70% of patients with primary Sjogren's syndrome, making it the most associated autoantibody for this condition.

Anti-RNP autoantibodies are not typically associated with primary Sjogren's syndrome. They are more commonly seen in mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD), which presents with features of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.

Anti-smooth muscle autoantibodies are not linked to primary Sjogren's syndrome either. These antibodies are mainly associated with autoimmune hepatitis, a chronic liver disease characterised by immune-mediated hepatocyte injury.

Anti-centromere autoantibodies are also not related to primary Sjogren's syndrome. They have a strong association with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (previously known as CREST syndrome: Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasias).

Finally, Anti-Sm autoantibodies are specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are not typically found in primary Sjogren's syndrome. While some patients may have overlapping features of both conditions due to their autoimmune nature, anti-Sm antibodies remain specific for diagnosing SLE.

question_notes:
The correct answer is Anti-Ro. Primary Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterised by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands, particularly the salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to symptoms such as dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca). Anti-Ro (also known as SS-A) autoantibodies are found in approximately 60-70% of patients with primary Sjogren's syndrome, making it the most associated autoantibody for this condition.

Anti-smooth muscle autoantibodies are not linked to primary Sjogren's syndrome either. These antibodies are mainly associated with autoimmune hepatitis, a chronic liver disease characterised by immune-mediated hepatocyte injury.

Anti-centromere autoantibodies are also not related to primary Sjogren's syndrome. They have a strong association with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (previously known as CREST syndrome: Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasias).

Finally, Anti-Sm autoantibodies are specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are not typically found in primary Sjogren's syndrome. While some patients may have overlapping features of both conditions due to their autoimmune nature, anti-Sm antibodies remain specific for diagnosing SLE.
title: Sjogren's syndrome
body:
Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder affecting exocrine glands resulting in dry mucosal surfaces. It may be primary (PSS) or secondary to rheumatoid arthritis or other connective tissue disorders, where it usually develops around 10 years after the initial onset. Sjogren's syndrome is much more common in females (ratio 9:1). There is a marked increased risk of lymphoid malignancy (40-60 fold).

Features
  • dry eyes: keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • dry mouth
  • vaginal dryness
  • arthralgia
  • Raynaud's, myalgia
  • sensory polyneuropathy
  • recurrent episodes of parotitis
  • renal tubular acidosis (usually subclinical)

Investigation
  • rheumatoid factor (RF) positive in nearly 50% of patients
  • ANA positive in 70%
  • anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies in 70% of patients with PSS
  • anti-La (SSB) antibodies in 30% of patients with PSS
  • Schirmer's test: filter paper near conjunctival sac to measure tear formation
  • histology: focal lymphocytic infiltration
  • also: hypergammaglobulinaemia, low C4

Management
  • artificial saliva and tears
  • pilocarpine may be helpful to stimulate saliva production
media:
Sjogren's syndrome
Osmosis - YouTube70

questions:
A 35-year-old runner presents with a 2-week history of posterior heel pain, worse after exercise and in the morning. On examination, there is tenderness over the Achilles tendon, but the calf squeeze test is normal.

Select the single most appropriate initial management from the options below.
notes:
Advise rest and simple analgesia is the correct answer. The clinical presentation of gradual-onset posterior heel pain, exacerbated by activity and associated with morning stiffness, is characteristic of Achilles tendinopathy. The normal calf squeeze test (Simmonds' test) makes a complete tendon rupture highly unlikely. According to UK guidelines (NICE CKS), the initial management for Achilles tendinopathy is conservative. This involves advising the patient to reduce or modify precipitating activities (relative rest) to allow the tendon to heal. Simple analgesia, such as paracetamol or a short course of a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) like ibuprofen (if no contraindications exist), can help manage the pain and inflammation. This initial conservative approach is often sufficient to resolve symptoms. If the pain does not improve after a week or two of these measures, then referral to physiotherapy for a structured exercise programme would be the next appropriate step.

Urgent referral to orthopaedics is incorrect. This management step is reserved for patients with a suspected acute Achilles tendon rupture. A rupture typically presents with a sudden 'pop' or a sensation of being kicked in the back of the leg during activity, followed by an immediate inability to weight-bear. The examination finding of a normal calf squeeze test in this scenario effectively rules out a complete rupture, making an urgent referral unnecessary. The history of a gradual onset over two weeks also points away from an acute rupture and towards a tendinopathy.

Referral for physiotherapy is a key component of managing Achilles tendinopathy but is not the most appropriate initial step. While eccentric calf muscle strengthening exercises, guided by a physiotherapist, are the mainstay of treatment for persistent symptoms, initial management should focus on settling the acute inflammatory phase. A period of relative rest, activity modification, and simple analgesia should be trialled first. If symptoms fail to improve with these simple measures, then a referral to physiotherapy is indicated to commence a rehabilitation programme and address any underlying biomechanical issues.

Request an ultrasound scan is not indicated at this stage. The diagnosis of Achilles tendinopathy is primarily a clinical one, based on the history and examination findings presented. Imaging is not required to confirm the diagnosis. An ultrasound scan is the first-line imaging modality when there is clinical suspicion of an Achilles tendon rupture (e.g., a positive calf squeeze test or a palpable gap in the tendon) or if the diagnosis is uncertain. As the clinical picture here is classic for tendinopathy, proceeding directly to imaging would be an unnecessary use of resources.

Arrange corticosteroid injection is inappropriate and potentially harmful. While corticosteroid injections are used for some other tendinopathies, they are generally contraindicated for Achilles tendinopathy. Injecting corticosteroid into or around the Achilles tendon is associated with an increased risk of tendon weakening and subsequent rupture. This can lead to significant long-term morbidity. Therefore, this option represents a management error and should be avoided.

Select the single most appropriate initial management from the options below.

title: Achilles tendon disorders
body:
Achilles tendon disorders are the most common cause of posterior heel pain. Possible presentations include tendinopathy (tendinitis), partial tear and complete rupture of the Achilles tendon.

Risk factors
  • quinolone use (e.g. ciprofloxacin) is associated with tendon disorders
  • hypercholesterolaemia (predisposes to tendon xanthomata)


Achilles tendinopathy (tendinitis)

Features
  • gradual onset of posterior heel pain that is worse following activity
  • morning pain and stiffness are common

The management is typically supportive
  • simple analgesia
  • reduction in precipitating activities
  • calf muscle eccentric exercises: this may be self-directed or under the guidance of physiotherapy


Achilles tendon rupture

Achilles tendon rupture should be suspected if the person describes the following whilst playing a sport or running; an audible 'pop' in the ankle, sudden onset significant pain in the calf or ankle or the inability to walk or continue the sport.

An examination should be conducted using Simmond's triad, to help exclude Achilles tendon rupture. This can be performed by asking the patient to lie prone with their feet over the edge of the bed. The examiner should look for an abnormal angle of declination; Achilles tendon rupture may lead to greater dorsiflexion of the injured foot compared to the uninjured limb. They should also feel for a gap in the tendon and gently squeeze the calf muscles if there is an acute rupture of the Achilles tendon the injured foot will stay in the neutral position when the calf is squeezed.

Ultrasound is the initial imaging modality of choice for suspected Achilles tendon rupture

An acute referral should be made to an orthopaedic specialist following a suspected rupture.
concept: Achilles tendonitis management: rest, NSAIDs, and physio if symptoms persist beyond 7 days
media:
Achilles Tendonitis and Tendon Rupture - Overview

Understanding Achilles Tendinopathy (Achilles Tendinitis)

2985.concept_text: Achilles tendonitis management: rest, NSAIDs, and physio if symptoms persist beyond 7 days

4563.concept_text: Ultrasound is the initial imaging modality of choice for suspected Achilles tendon rupture

questions: A 60-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a three week history of breathlessness and a dry cough. She does not smoke and drinks 15 units of alcohol a week. There is a target rash present on both her lower limbs. Her chest x-ray shows reticulo-nodular shadowing of the right lung. A diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia is made. What is the most likely organism causing her symptoms?
notes:
The dry cough, erythema multiforme (symmetrical target shaped rash with a central blister) and the radiological findings point to a diagnosis of Mycoplasma.

Although pneumococcal pneumonia is the most common pneumonia in the community, you would expect lobar consolidation on x-ray as well as a productive, rather than dry, cough.

Klebsiella occurs in alcoholics, and although the woman drinks more than her allowance (for women this is 14 units a week) it is not at the level where it would predispose her to Klebsiella. Furthermore, it typically causes a cavitating pneumonia of the upper lobes.
question: A 60-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a three week history of breathlessness and a dry cough. She does not smoke and drinks 15 units of alcohol a week. There is a target rash present on both her lower limbs. Her chest x-ray shows reticulo-nodular shadowing of the right lung. A diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia is made. What is the most likely organism causing her symptoms?
question_notes:
The dry cough, erythema multiforme (symmetrical target shaped rash with a central blister) and the radiological findings point to a diagnosis of Mycoplasma.

Although pneumococcal pneumonia is the most common pneumonia in the community, you would expect lobar consolidation on x-ray as well as a productive, rather than dry, cough.

Klebsiella occurs in alcoholics, and although the woman drinks more than her allowance (for women this is 14 units a week) it is not at the level where it would predispose her to Klebsiella. Furthermore, it typically causes a cavitating pneumonia of the upper lobes.
title: Mycoplasma pneumoniae
body:
Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a cause of atypical pneumonia that often affects younger patients. It is associated with a number of characteristic complications such as erythema multiforme and cold autoimmune haemolytic anaemia. Epidemics of Mycoplasma pneumoniae classically occur every 4 years. It is important to recognise atypical pneumonia as it may not respond to penicillins or cephalosporins due to it lacking a peptidoglycan cell wall.

Features
  • the disease typically has a prolonged and gradual onset
  • flu-like symptoms classically precede a dry cough
  • bilateral consolidation on x-ray
  • complications may occur as below

Complications
  • cold agglutins (IgM): may cause an haemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopenia
  • erythema multiforme, erythema nodosum
  • meningoencephalitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome and other immune-mediated neurological diseases
  • bullous myringitis: painful vesicles on the tympanic membrane
  • pericarditis/myocarditis
  • gastrointestinal: hepatitis, pancreatitis
  • renal: acute glomerulonephritis

Investigations
  • diagnosis is generally by Mycoplasma serology
  • positive cold agglutination test → peripheral blood smear may show red blood cell agglutination

Management
  • doxycycline or a macrolide (e.g. erythromycin/clarithromycin)

Comparison of Legionella and Mycoplasma pneumonia
links:
DermNet NZ156
Erythema multiforme
media:
Mycoplasma
Townsend Teaching - YouTube10
 
Mycoplasma pneumoniae
Osmosis - YouTube102

2350.concept_text: Mycoplasma is associated with erythema multiforme

8401.concept_text: Stereotypical history of mycoplasma pneumonia: worsening flu-like symptoms and a dry cough. Erythema multiforme is noted on examination

8402.concept_text: Mycoplasma pneumoniae - may cause a positive cold agglutination test

8405.concept_text: Mycoplasma pneumoniae patient with anaemia, raised LDH, raised unconjugated bilirubin --> autoimmune haemolytic anaemia

questions:
A 27-year-old man who has recently moved to the UK from Uganda presents complaining of fatigue and purple skin lesions all over his body. On examination he has multiple raised purple lesions on his trunk and arms. You also notice some smaller purple lesions in his mouth. He has recently started taking acyclovir for herpes zoster infection.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Raised purple lesions is a classic description of Kaposi's sarcoma suggesting he has underlying HIV infection. HIV has a high prevalence in Uganda and the recent herpes zoster infection suggests he may have underlying immunocompromise.

Dermatofibromas are usually small pink/red nodules that are characteristically very firm and would not be found in the mouth. Psoriasis presents with red, scaly lesions and again is not seen on mucosal surfaces. A drug reaction is unlikely to present like this. A haemangioma can present with a purple raised lesion but again it would be unusual to see them in the mouth and Kaposi's sarcoma is much more likely in this case.

title: HIV: Kaposi's sarcoma
body:
Kaposi's sarcoma
  • caused by HHV-8 (human herpes virus 8)
  • presents as purple papules or plaques on the skin or mucosa (e.g. gastrointestinal and respiratory tract)
  • skin lesions may later ulcerate
  • respiratory involvement may cause massive haemoptysis and pleural effusion
  • radiotherapy + resection

Kaposi's sarcoma in a patient with HIV

questions: A 36-year-old man presents with dyspepsia. No alarm symptoms are present. This is his first episode and he has no significant medical history of note. A test-and-treat strategy is agreed upon. What is the most appropriate investigation to test for Helicobacter pylori?
notes:
The correct answer is the 13C-urea breath test, which is the recommended first-line non-invasive test for Helicobacter pylori in the test-and-treat strategy according to NICE guidelines. This test has excellent sensitivity (95%) and specificity (95-100%). The patient ingests 13C-labelled urea, which is metabolised by H. pylori urease if present, producing labelled CO2 that can be detected in exhaled breath. The test is particularly suitable in this case as the patient is presenting with uncomplicated dyspepsia without alarm symptoms, making non-invasive testing appropriate.

Gastric biopsy is an invasive procedure requiring endoscopy, which is not indicated as a first-line investigation in uncomplicated dyspepsia without alarm symptoms in a young patient. While it provides excellent diagnostic accuracy and allows histological examination, it carries unnecessary risks and costs in this clinical scenario.

The CLO test (rapid urease test) also requires endoscopic biopsy and is therefore not appropriate as a first-line test in this case. While it provides rapid results and is useful when endoscopy is being performed for other reasons, it is too invasive for the test-and-treat strategy in primary care.

Stool culture is not a recommended method for diagnosing H. pylori infection. While stool antigen testing is an acceptable alternative to urea breath testing, culture of H. pylori from stool is not routinely performed and has poor sensitivity.

The hydrogen breath test is not used for detecting H. pylori infection. This test is instead used to diagnose small intestinal bacterial overgrowth or carbohydrate malabsorption conditions such as lactose intolerance. It measures hydrogen produced by bacterial fermentation of carbohydrates rather than the urease activity of H. pylori.

title: Helicobacter pylori: tests
body:
Urea breath test
  • patients consume a drink containing carbon isotope 13 (13C) enriched urea
  • urea is broken down by H. pylori urease
  • after 30 mins patient exhale into a glass tube
  • mass spectrometry analysis calculates the amount of 13C CO2
  • should not be performed within 4 weeks of treatment with an antibacterial or within 2 weeks of an antisecretory drug (e.g. a proton pump inhibitor)
  • sensitivity 95-98%, specificity 97-98%
  • may be used to check for H. pylori eradication

Rapid urease test (e.g. CLO test)
  • biopsy sample is mixed with urea and pH indicator
  • colour change if H pylori urease activity
  • sensitivity 90-95%, specificity 95-98%

Serum antibody
  • remains positive after eradication
  • sensitivity 85%, specificity 80%

Culture of gastric biopsy
  • provide information on antibiotic sensitivity
  • sensitivity 70%, specificity 100%

Gastric biopsy
  • histological evaluation alone, no culture
  • sensitivity 95-99%, specificity 95-99%

Stool antigen test
  • sensitivity 90%, specificity 95%
links:
BNF78
Helicobacter pylori infection


Public Health England32
Helicobacter Pylori: Diagnosis and Treatment
media:
Helicobacter pylori
Osmosis - YouTube60
 
Helicobacter pylori
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube24

644.concept_text: Urea breath test - no antibiotics in past 4 weeks, no antisecretory drugs (e.g. PPI) in past 2 weeks

4190.concept_text: Urea breath test is the only test recommended for H. pylori post-eradication therapy

questions: At which point in the menstrual cycle do progesterone levels peak?
notes: Progesterone is secreted by the corpus luteum following ovulation. Whilst the GPST contains few questions about physiology a basic understanding is required to understand contraception, fertility problems and gynaecological disorders
question: At which point in the menstrual cycle do progesterone levels peak?
question_notes: Progesterone is secreted by the corpus luteum following ovulation. Whilst the GPST contains few questions about physiology a basic understanding is required to understand contraception, fertility problems and gynaecological disorders
title: Menstrual cycle
body:
The menstrual cycle may be divided into the following phases:

Days
Menstruation1-4
Follicular phase (proliferative phase)5-13
Ovulation14
Luteal phase (secretory phase)15-28

Image sourced from Wikipedia

Further details are given in the table below

Follicular phase (proliferative phase)Luteal phase (secretory phase)
Ovarian histologyA number of follicles develop.

One follicle will become dominant around the mid-follicular phase		Corpus luteum
Endometrial histologyProliferation of endometriumEndometrium changes to secretory lining under influence of progesterone
HormonesA rise in FSH results in the development of follicles which in turn secrete oestradiol

When the egg has matured, it secretes enough oestradiol to trigger the acute release of LH. This in turn leads to ovulation		Progesterone secreted by corpus luteum rises through the luteal phase.

If fertilisation does not occur the corpus luteum will degenerate and progesterone levels fall

Oestradiol levels also rise again during the luteal phase
Cervical mucusFollowing menstruation the mucus is thick and forms a plug across the external os

Just prior to ovulation the mucus becomes clear, acellular, low viscosity. It also becomes 'stretchy' - a quality termed spinnbarkeit		Under the influence of progesterone it becomes thick, scant, and tacky
Basal body temperatureFalls prior to ovulation due to the influence of oestradiolRises following ovulation in response to higher progesterone levels
links:
Wikipedia53
Menstrual cycle (including diagram)
media:
Understanding the Menstrual Cycle
Zero to Finals - YouTube331
 
Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System
Osmosis - YouTube31
 
The menstrual cycle
Osmosis - YouTube21
 
Female Reproductive System - Menstrual Cycle, Hormones and Regulation
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube01

options: Body mass index percentile adjusted to age and gender
questions: A 9-year-old girl is brought to surgery as her mother is concerned that she is too fat. This has now been a problem for over two years and mum feels this is holding her back at school. What is the most appropriate method to ascertain how obese she is?
notes:
The most appropriate method to ascertain how obese the 9-year-old girl is would be the Body mass index percentile adjusted to age and gender. This is because BMI percentiles take into account the child's age, sex, weight, and height, providing a more accurate assessment of obesity in children and adolescents than using just BMI alone. The World Health Organisation (WHO) growth reference charts are commonly used in the UK for this purpose.

Using only Body mass index as a measure of obesity may not be suitable for children and adolescents because their body composition changes significantly with growth and development. Therefore, it is essential to consider age and gender when assessing their weight status.

Weight plotted on percentile chart can provide some information about the child's growth pattern but does not give an accurate assessment of obesity since it does not take into consideration the height of the child. This can lead to misinterpretations regarding their weight status.

Relying on Mother's perception of her child's weight status is not a reliable method to determine obesity. Parents may have biased opinions or lack awareness about healthy weight ranges for children at different ages and stages of development.

Finally, using Waist circumference as a sole indicator of obesity might not be sufficient in children. Although it can indicate central adiposity (fat distribution) which is associated with an increased risk of metabolic complications such as type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease, waist circumference alone does not provide a comprehensive picture of overall obesity in children. It should be used alongside other measures like BMI percentile adjusted for age and gender to obtain a more accurate evaluation.

question_notes:
The most appropriate method to ascertain how obese the 9-year-old girl is would be the Body mass index percentile adjusted to age and gender. This is because BMI percentiles take into account the child's age, sex, weight, and height, providing a more accurate assessment of obesity in children and adolescents than using just BMI alone. The World Health Organisation (WHO) growth reference charts are commonly used in the UK for this purpose.

Using only Body mass index as a measure of obesity may not be suitable for children and adolescents because their body composition changes significantly with growth and development. Therefore, it is essential to consider age and gender when assessing their weight status.

Weight plotted on percentile chart can provide some information about the child's growth pattern but does not give an accurate assessment of obesity since it does not take into consideration the height of the child. This can lead to misinterpretations regarding their weight status.

Relying on Mother's perception of her child's weight status is not a reliable method to determine obesity. Parents may have biased opinions or lack awareness about healthy weight ranges for children at different ages and stages of development.

Finally, using Waist circumference as a sole indicator of obesity might not be sufficient in children. Although it can indicate central adiposity (fat distribution) which is associated with an increased risk of metabolic complications such as type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease, waist circumference alone does not provide a comprehensive picture of overall obesity in children. It should be used alongside other measures like BMI percentile adjusted for age and gender to obtain a more accurate evaluation.
title: Obesity in children
body:
Defining obesity is more difficult in children than adults as body mass index (BMI) varies with age. BMI percentile charts are therefore needed to make an accurate assessment. Recent NICE guidelines suggest to use 'UK 1990 BMI charts to give age- and gender-specific information'

NICE recommend
  • consider tailored clinical intervention if BMI at 91st centile or above.
  • consider assessing for comorbidities if BMI at 98th centile or above

By far the most common cause of obesity in childhood is lifestyle factors. Other associations of obesity in children include:
  • Asian children: four times more likely to be obese than white children
  • female children
  • taller children: children with obesity are often above the 50th percentile in height

Cause of obesity in children
  • growth hormone deficiency
  • hypothyroidism
  • Down's syndrome
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Prader-Willi syndrome

Consequences of obesity in children
  • orthopaedic problems: slipped upper femoral epiphyses, Blount's disease (a development abnormality of the tibia resulting in bowing of the legs), musculoskeletal pains
  • psychological consequences: poor self-esteem, bullying
  • sleep apnoea
  • benign intracranial hypertension
  • long-term consequences: increased incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension and ischaemic heart disease
links:
NICE22
2014 Obesity guidelines


SIGN31
Obesity guidelines

questions:
A 34-year-old overweight woman presents to the emergency department feeling feverish with vaginal bleeding and some foul-smelling discharge. A pregnancy test is positive and her vital signs are stable. She needs pads but only changes these every few hours. When asked, she discloses this is her second miscarriage and that an ultrasound last week showed a twin intrauterine pregnancy. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. After discussing options with you she explains she wants to miscarry at home without medical or surgical intervention.

What part of her history might make this unsuitable?
notes:
Foul-smelling discharge is correct. This suggests there may be an infection present, which can be a contraindication to expectant management. It is not an absolute contraindication, but a discussion should be had as to whether medical or surgical management may be more appropriate. It is important the miscarriage is managed promptly and that antibiotics are given to prevent sepsis and/or haemorrhage.

High BMI is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management.

Moderate bleeding is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management. NICE guidelines state that if the woman is at increased risk of haemorrhage (for example, she is in the late first trimester) or she is at increased risk from the effects of haemorrhage (for example, if she has coagulopathies or is unable to have a blood transfusion), then other management options should be discussed. However, bleeding is a normal part of miscarriage.

Second miscarriage is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management. However, if it was a third consecutive miscarriage it would be considered recurrent and management options, including surgical, should be discussed if they wish to analyse the products of conception e.g. for karyotyping.

Twin pregnancy is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management unless the pregnancy is more advanced and the woman is thought to be at increased risk of haemorrhage.
question:
A 34-year-old overweight woman presents to the emergency department feeling feverish with vaginal bleeding and some foul-smelling discharge. A pregnancy test is positive and her vital signs are stable. She needs pads but only changes these every few hours. When asked, she discloses this is her second miscarriage and that an ultrasound last week showed a twin intrauterine pregnancy. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. After discussing options with you she explains she wants to miscarry at home without medical or surgical intervention.

What part of her history might make this unsuitable?
question_notes:
Foul-smelling discharge is correct. This suggests there may be an infection present, which can be a contraindication to expectant management. It is not an absolute contraindication, but a discussion should be had as to whether medical or surgical management may be more appropriate. It is important the miscarriage is managed promptly and that antibiotics are given to prevent sepsis and/or haemorrhage.

High BMI is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management.

Moderate bleeding is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management. NICE guidelines state that if the woman is at increased risk of haemorrhage (for example, she is in the late first trimester) or she is at increased risk from the effects of haemorrhage (for example, if she has coagulopathies or is unable to have a blood transfusion), then other management options should be discussed. However, bleeding is a normal part of miscarriage.

Second miscarriage is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management. However, if it was a third consecutive miscarriage it would be considered recurrent and management options, including surgical, should be discussed if they wish to analyse the products of conception e.g. for karyotyping.

Twin pregnancy is incorrect. This is not a contraindication to expectant management unless the pregnancy is more advanced and the woman is thought to be at increased risk of haemorrhage.
title: Miscarriage: management
body:
In the 2023 NICE guidelines, 3 types of management for miscarriage were discussed:

Expectant management
  • 'Waiting for a spontaneous miscarriage'
  • First-line and involves waiting for 7-14 days for the miscarriage to complete spontaneously
  • If expectant management is unsuccessful then medical or surgical management may be offered

Some situations are better managed medically or surgically. NICE list the following:
  • increased risk of haemorrhage
    • she is in the late first trimester
    • if she has coagulopathies or is unable to have a blood transfusion
  • previous adverse and/or traumatic experience associated with pregnancy (for example, stillbirth, miscarriage or antepartum haemorrhage)
  • evidence of infection

Medical management:
  • missed miscarriage
    • oral mifepristone. Mifepristone is a progesterone receptor antagonist → weakening of attachment to the endometrial wall + cervical softening and dilation + induction of uterine contractions
    • 48 hours later, misoprostol (vaginal, oral or sublingual) unless the gestational sac has already been passed. Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analogue, binds to myometrial cells → strong myometrial contractions → expulsion of products of conception
    • if bleeding has not started within 48 hours after misoprostol treatment, they should contact their healthcare professional
  • incomplete miscarriage
    • a single dose of misoprostol (vaginal, oral or sublingual)
  • women should be offered antiemetics and pain relief
  • a pregnancy test should be performed at 3 weeks

Surgical management
  • 'Undergoing a surgical procedure under local or general anaesthetic'
  • The two main options are vacuum aspiration (suction curettage) or surgical management in theatre
  • Vacuum aspiration is done under local anaesthetic as an outpatient
- Surgical management is done in theatre under general anaesthetic. This was previously referred to as 'Evacuation of retained products of conception'
concept: Miscarriage - expectant management is not suitable if evidence of infection or increased risk of haemorrhage
links:
NICE66
2023 Ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage: diagnosis and initial management

3765.concept_text: Miscarriage - expectant management is not suitable if evidence of infection or increased risk of haemorrhage

options: The fetal head may rotate spontaneously to an OA position
Augmentation should be avoided if labour is slow
If instrumentation is necessary, a ventouse is associated with the most successful outcomes
Mothers will generally experience a later urge to push than if position was OA
questions: A 30-year-old para 1+0 has presented at term in labour. On vaginal examination, the occiput can be palpated posteriorly (near the sacrum). Which of these is correct regarding your further management of these patients?
notes:
1: Correct.
2: Delivery is possible in the OP position, however labour is likely to be longer and more painful.
3: Augmentation should be used if progress is slow.
4: Kielland's forceps are associated with the most successful outcomes, however require particular expertise.
5: Generally, women will experience an earlier urge to push in OP than OA.
question: A 30-year-old para 1+0 has presented at term in labour. On vaginal examination, the occiput can be palpated posteriorly (near the sacrum). Which of these is correct regarding your further management of these patients?
question_notes:
1: Correct.
2: Delivery is possible in the OP position, however labour is likely to be longer and more painful.
3: Augmentation should be used if progress is slow.
4: Kielland's forceps are associated with the most successful outcomes, however require particular expertise.
5: Generally, women will experience an earlier urge to push in OP than OA.
title: Labour: stage 2
body:
Labour may be divided in to three stages
  • stage 1: from the onset of true labour to when the cervix is fully dilated
  • stage 2: from full dilation to delivery of the fetus
  • stage 3: from delivery of fetus to when the placenta and membranes have been completely delivered

Stage 2 - from full dilation to delivery of the fetus
  • 'passive second stage' refers to the 2nd stage but in the absence of pushing (normal)
  • active second stage' refers to the active process of maternal pushing
  • less painful than 1st (pushing masks pain)
  • lasts approximately 1 hours
  • if longer than 1 hour (can be left longer if epidural) consider Ventouse extraction, forceps delivery or caesarean section
  • episiotomy may be necessary following crowning
  • associated with transient fetal bradycardia
media:
Stages of labor
Osmosis - YouTube50

questions: What is the most useful investigation to screen for the complications of Kawasaki disease?
notes:
The correct answer is Echocardiogram. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that predominantly affects children. It can lead to coronary artery aneurysms as a complication, which can be fatal if not detected and managed promptly. An echocardiogram is the most useful investigation for screening these complications as it provides direct visualisation of the coronary arteries and can detect aneurysms or dilatations. According to UK guidelines, all patients diagnosed with Kawasaki disease should have an echocardiogram at diagnosis, then again at 1-2 weeks and 6-8 weeks after treatment.

Lumbar puncture is not the most useful investigation in this context. While Kawasaki disease can present with meningeal irritation signs mimicking meningitis, lumbar puncture primarily helps in diagnosing central nervous system infections or measuring cerebrospinal fluid pressure, rather than detecting the cardiovascular complications of Kawasaki disease.

A Coronary angiogram would provide detailed images of the coronary arteries and could indeed identify aneurysms. However, it's invasive nature, requirement for radiation exposure and contrast use make it less suitable as a screening test compared to echocardiography.

MRI of posterior fossa is used in evaluating brain structures like cerebellum and brainstem. While neurological symptoms may occur in Kawasaki disease due to systemic inflammation, they are not common and MRI does not help identify cardiac complications which are more prevalent and serious.

Finally, an ECG might show non-specific changes such as sinus tachycardia or arrhythmias in acute phase of Kawasaki disease but it does not have sensitivity or specificity for detecting coronary artery abnormalities linked with this condition. Therefore, while ECG has its place in evaluating acute symptoms or monitoring during treatment stages, it's not the best choice for screening complications of Kawasaki disease.

title: Kawasaki disease
body:
Kawasaki disease is a type of vasculitis which is predominately seen in children. Whilst Kawasaki disease is uncommon it is important to recognise as it may cause potentially serious complications, including coronary artery aneurysms.

Features
  • high-grade fever which lasts for > 5 days. Fever is characteristically resistant to antipyretics
  • conjunctival injection
  • bright red, cracked lips
  • strawberry tongue
  • cervical lymphadenopathy
  • red palms of the hands and the soles of the feet which later peel

Kawasaki disease is a clinical diagnosis as there is no specific diagnostic test.

Management
  • high-dose aspirin
    • Kawasaki disease is one of the few indications for the use of aspirin in children. Due to the risk of Reye's syndrome aspirin is normally contraindicated in children
  • intravenous immunoglobulin
  • echocardiogram (rather than angiography) is used as the initial screening test for coronary artery aneurysms

Complications
  • coronary artery aneurysm
concept: Coronary artery aneurysms are a complication of Kawasaki disease and this should be screened for with an echocardiogram

2892.concept_text: Coronary artery aneurysms are a complication of Kawasaki disease and this should be screened for with an echocardiogram

2893.concept_text: High dose aspirin is indicated in Kawasaki disease, despite it usually being contraindicated in children

2894.concept_text: High fever lasting >5 days, red palms with desquamation and strawberry tongue are indicative of Kawasaki disease
